skill.name: ensembl-database
skill.description: Query Ensembl genome database REST API for 250+ species. Gene lookups, sequence retrieval, variant analysis, comparative genomics, orthologs, VEP predictions, for genomic research.
skill.summary: Query Ensembl genome database REST API for 250+ species. Gene lookups, sequence retrieval, variant a...
skill.author: K-Dense Inc.

security_audit.summary: The skill includes a Python script that performs documented HTTP requests to the official Ensembl REST API. No credential harvesting, environment access, or filesystem traversal was found. Network calls are limited to rest.ensembl.org and grch37.rest.ensembl.org only.

low_findings.title: HTTP requests to external Ensembl endpoints
low_findings.description: The script issues outbound HTTP requests using requests library. Lines 83-86 show: "response = requests.post(url, headers=headers, json=data)" and "response = requests.get(url, headers=headers, params=params)". This is expected for API access but still allows query data to leave the machine.

low_findings.title: Executable Python CLI script present
low_findings.description: The repository includes a runnable Python script with a shebang line at line 1: "#!/usr/bin/env python3". Executable scripts can be run by users but this is a standard CLI pattern for research tools.

content.value_statement: You need reliable gene, variant, and sequence data across species. This skill provides Ensembl REST queries with a ready-to-run Python client for genomic research.
actual_capabilities: Look up genes by symbol with optional transcript expansion
Retrieve sequences by Ensembl ID or genomic region in JSON or FASTA format
Query variant data by rsID with population frequency information
Predict variant effects using VEP HGVS notation
Find orthologs for genes across different species
Map coordinates between genome assemblies (GRCh37 to GRCh38)
limitations: Requires network access to Ensembl REST servers
Subject to Ensembl rate limits (15 requests per second for anonymous users)
Only provides data available in current Ensembl releases

use_cases.title: Gene annotation lookup
use_cases.description: Find gene coordinates, transcripts, and identifiers from a symbol or Ensembl ID.

use_cases.title: Variant consequence check
use_cases.description: Run VEP on an HGVS variant and summarize predicted functional effects.

use_cases.title: Ortholog discovery
use_cases.description: Identify orthologs for a gene and review homology results across species.

prompt_templates.title: Gene lookup
prompt_templates.prompt: Look up the human gene BRCA2 and summarize its location and main transcripts.

prompt_templates.title: Sequence retrieval
prompt_templates.prompt: Get the FASTA sequence for ENSG00000139618 and report the sequence length.

prompt_templates.title: Variant analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Run VEP for ENST00000380152.7:c.803C>T in human and summarize key consequences.

prompt_templates.title: Ortholog comparison
prompt_templates.prompt: Find mouse orthologs for ENSG00000139618 and compare gene names and IDs.

output_examples.input: Check variant rs699 in human and summarize major annotations.
output: Variant rs699 is a biallelic SNP found in the data
Associated variant IDs and clinical significance are reported

best_practices: Use supported species names and verify assembly version before querying
Handle 429 responses with backoff and retry using Retry-After header
Cache frequent queries to reduce API load and improve performance
anti_patterns: Sending large query batches without implementing rate limiting
Requesting unsupported species or assemblies that do not exist in Ensembl
Assuming Ensembl covers all organisms or all data types

faq.question: Is this compatible with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code?
faq.answer: Yes. The prompts and workflows are designed to work on all three platforms.

faq.question: What limits should I expect?
faq.answer: Anonymous access is rate limited to 15 requests per second and may return 429 responses during bursts.

faq.question: Can I integrate this into a pipeline?
faq.answer: Yes. Use the provided Python script or REST patterns for automation in research workflows.

faq.question: Does it access my local data or secrets?
faq.answer: No. The script only sends query parameters to Ensembl REST endpoints and does not access local files.

faq.question: What if a request fails?
faq.answer: Retry with exponential backoff, verify IDs and species names, and check Ensembl service status.

faq.question: How does it compare to manual browsing?
faq.answer: It automates lookups and batch queries programmatically without requiring the web interface.
